column17:
Was the participant aware of the goal?
1= YES  0 = NO
column18: Transcribe the written answer of each participant's guess  of the study's goal.
I imagine it has something to do with testing different positions the pen can be held in and how effective they are, but it wouldn't surprise me if it were something different entirely.
I think that the purpose of the experiment is to see the extent to which holding a pen would affect one's disposition.

By having subjects form the facial of scowling/worry by holding the pen in its correct position, this experiment was designed to test how people's amusement changed based on performed facial expression. (I came up with this theory after performing the tests.)

I think the purpose is to show how difficult it can be to relearn how to do menial tasks in a different way, like trying to learn to ride a backwards bicycle after already knowing how to ride a normal bike. I also think it may be about the accuracy of how well a person performs a task compared to how well they think they did.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I think the purpose is to make people more aware of technologies and hardships in regard to disabilities related to motor skills. I think it also is to show people how difficult it can be, but that as time and practice occurs, it should get easier. Perhaps encouragment in a sense? But broadly to see how people react to being put in positions of "discomfort".

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I believe the purpose of the experiment was to neurologically evaluate the connection our brain has with other parts of the body, specifically in regard to motivational motor control. I think that with the relevant technological applications can be created to help those that may have motor impairment.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To alert participants of the comparative difficulties those necessitating this and other accomodations experience on a day-to-day basis and also to observe perhaps how quickly someone can adapt to necessary adaptations when pressed to do so.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To study the physical and emotional reactions one might have to being forced to write with their mouths. Also, to study the difficulty one might feel in apprehending this method.
Look at how strength of different body parts are built up over time, use of uncommon body parts for common tasks

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To highlight how difficult it can be for disabled people to use objects/do activities that many people consider easy.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] Address social/psychological implications of disabled/paralyzed individuals and their ability/style of communication.
To evaluate how individuals function under this situation and also to evaluate how people perceive themselves and people with disabilities.
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] to try to create better ways of dealing w/disabilities and researching insecurities

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To understand how people of disability feel when having confronted with tasks. To perhaps come up with better ways/technology to enhance them.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] The purpose of the experiment might be to investigate alternative methods for doing everyday tasks for those who are unable to do them in a normal fashion.  Additionally, the researcher might be investigating people's mental and emotional perceptions of these alternatives, as well as their ability to learn, adapt, and follow an established set of rules regarding these alternative methods.
To understand the ability of someone who is not impaired completing impaired tasks. Also, to understand how someone who is impaired might feel during everyday tasks.
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] no idea
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] (none given)
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To understand how people are conscious of what they do that can be perceived as out of the ordinary (?)

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To find a cheap, everyday method for those who may be physically impaired. To see if we think things are funnier or less amusing with our face is having to strain its muscles in a very specific way.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] Perhaps to examine the role of self-perception/the creation of image of self, particularly in regard to judgement of others.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] Smiling face links to better evaluation of ability & more easily amused by comics. Humor rating links to ability to underline.
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To discover cheaper methods of alternative technologies to help those that are physically disabled.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To analyze the use of alternate methods that people with disabilities may encounter, and to study whether or not more expensive equipment is necessary or if cheaper forms are sufficient.
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To asses mouth cordination

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] The purpose of this experiment as detailed before was to test cheaper alternatives to tech. that helps disabled people. But, I'm guessing it had more to do with how physical discomfort (ie holding pen in mouth) affects willingness to feel humor. Otherwise that piece seemed a little irrelevant!
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] Realized @ cartoon section that it's probably about the effects of facial expression on mood
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To test how fast we can adapt

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] Idk, for some of the content it said to hold the pen in your mouth while you rated the exercise, others did not give that explicit direction. Or maybe it had to do with being concerned w/how I look while holding the pen.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] Otensibly to learn about writing for people w/disabilities, but I'm guessing it was to see how well the subject could follow directions (proper pen holding) while given difficult tasks (writing w/mouth)

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To study our ability to use our brain to not only analyze what we're reading but also to use a part of our body & functions that we never use
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To see if shame associated with performing task in abnormal manner effects performance
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To know what it is like to live without my hands?

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To see how quickly people can adapt to using their body parts in a new way & to see how self-awareness of looking funny or different while doing something may affect how or how much disabled people choose to adapt to their disability.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] Purpose could be to gauge how affective someone is using their mouth to complete the tasks with the goal of finding new leads to development for people with disabilities

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To examine the extent to which I can perform tasks (that I usually do with my hands) using my teeth instead comfortably
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To see whether people are more easily amused when they're in physical discomfort.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To see if there are cheaper but equally as effective methods of alternative movement, probably for people who can no longer use their hands but can't afford expensive therapies/machineries to function

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I think the purpose is to study and understand how we can use certain parts of our bodies to accomplish different tasks that we do not typically do with these body parts.
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] Social views of disabilities, awareness of self and others used in a productive manner to innovate
column22: Micro biology, International Affairs, Spanish minor

column18: [NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] The purpose of this experiment is not only what was listed in the description, but also to bring awareness of physical disabilities as someone who has not experienced them before.
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To see how people react when they are told to do/usually do unusual things by themselves.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] It seemed like this was testing whether a mechanism that you held/was placed in your similar to the pen would be easy to use, navigate, move, be comfortable. It seemed like the mechanism could help someone who has little control over anything except their face/mouth.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] Hmm, not exactly sure. Could be anything from studying the different methods that people use to accomplish these tasks (and trends in these methods), how long people take to do them, how facial expressions can be different while attempting to accomplish a task, etc. Not exactly sure, though...I would love to know.

Make the participants briefly aware of what it would be like to have to use another part of your body for as simple a task as writing, as well as allow those conducting the expeirment to see how people adjust and react when given such a task.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I have an inkling the purpose was to test the facial feedback theory. I thought of this as I was reading the second cartoon.
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I'm not sure; possibly how one's awareness of others watching might affect performance.
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I think this experiment was to find how poorly we are able to adapt to different circumstances.
The purpose of the experiment is to test how well I can use my body to mimic tasks that people w/handicaps must do every day.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] This study is meant to promote new ways of using the body for simple tasks that others may not be able to do as simply. It also forces the participant to look at new ways in which the body can handle certain tasks.
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] Probably something to do either with the cartoons, or with levels of self-consciousness.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I think the purpose of this experiment is partially to show how challenging life can be with a disability, and partially to see if my performance of the tasks got better with practice and time.
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I believe the purpose of this experiment is to find alternative means to do everyday tasks.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] The purpose was to see how people dealt with different tasks with the "challenge" of the pen. If it significantly made it easier or harderto do. Maybe how our brains reacted..
[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To see how people rated themselves vs. their actual performance

The purpose of this experiment was to examine the impact individual perception/perspective has on performing an unusual task. To be brief: negative > lower performance, positive > higher performance. May hold implications towards how self-judgement influences one's idea of competency, perceived outside or during an acitivity.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To see or find how hard it is to write as if a handicap person when one doesn't have a handicap. The purpose may be to help develop a new way or technique for people with a disability to write in an easier and more efficient way.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I think the purpose of this study is to collect data on how people are able to adapt to adverse conditions. This was done by putting subjects through this condition.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] To gather data, regarding how realistic this hold is, comfort level + perofrmance relationship, for use in developing technologies for those who must use different ways to write

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] 1) To see if we turned the paper? 2) To look at our faces while we computed tasks (discomforted, frustrated, etc.) 3) To see if we can follow directions.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] to see how the solution would affect the social aspect of someone's life & to test it in different writing situations

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I  think the purpose of the experiment is to find out how people who do not have the possibility to hold a pen can still be able to perform similar task then people who can hold a pen in their hand. Also due to new touch screen technology people can be able to use them via this method.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I think it was about seeing what people think about when making the face or about if people can follow directions when left to a task if there is an easier way to do it if we'll do it
To research different and more comfortable ways for people to write if they cannot write traditionally. Possibly to better the pen-in-mouth technique.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I think the purpose of this experiment is to study the way in which people perform tasks w/parts of their body that they wouldn't normally use, and see the discomfort they feel both physically & psychologically when doing these tasks in this way.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I believe the purpose of this experiment was to become aware of how simple everyday tasks can become difficult if you were to change the way you approach them. You become more aware of your body & what it's doing.

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] I think the purpose of this experiment is to focus on how we as individuals communicate with one another and how it can be different for each and every one of us to communicate effectively. This experiment is used to understand the thoughts and reactions of each student.
To see how well and comfortably I could perform the tasks with the pen in my mouth in the correct position.
To better understand the brain's capacity for fine motor skills in people that do not normally struggle with menial tasks.

I think that it's showing how you might feel when people are watching you - does it impact you enough that you don't perform correctly? I think I tcould also show different people's motor skills although it isn't gender or age based so I think it mostly has to do with what you think other people are seeing you do. It does ask for age/gender below though so those could be contributing factors to one's instability.
I believe the purpose was to evaluate my performance using a pen with my mouth, in order to determine whether my motor skills were able to adjust to this unusual act.
To determine the difficulty of using your body to do things it is not used to. To shed light on how difficult it is for people with disabilities.
Figure out/let us know the feelings of disables when they use mouth to hold the pen or use parts of body which normal people do not use to do things.

To test people's perceptions when looking at those who are physically disabled and put them in a similar scenario to show how difficult and uncomfortable it is, and as a result find out how their perceptions change.
To show that there are different ways to do things, innovative ways to help people, but we usually just associate more technology + better outcomes.
To find out how comfortable people are with writing with their mouths, see how each person does…not too sure about the cartoons though!
To find alternatives to holding a pen without your hand. They're trying to find ways to create better technology for people with disabilities.

I think the purpose of the experiment was to study facial feedback: how forcing a smile can alter people's feelings/performances during certain tasks. The study also looked at how people use different parts of their body to complete tasks they wouldn't usually do with that part of their body.
I think the purpose of this experiment was to test an alternative to using a pen without using your hands.
To gage how practical/comfortable using non-typical body parts to write to see how necessary new expensive technologies are for people who are unable to use their hands to write.
To understand how people adapt to situations where they have limited resources
No idea
To see how people's amusement changes when they are doing something that makes them look funny/makes them feel uncomfortable
self-image
To assess how easily we may repurpose parts of our body to do things that are unfamiliar to it.
I think this experiment is conducted to study the relationship of motor skills with odd functions.
I think that the purpose is to how well people perform in tasks when they are at some type of disadvantage in which they are being watched and in which their appearance is different than normal.

To see how effective one could write w/some sort of impairment, but also to see how thoughtful they could be while doing so (words exercise). Afterwards, the frame of mind of the user is examined (good/bad mood)
To understand how people deal with physical incapacitaiton by using parts of their bodies to replace their "disabilities". Also how it affects them psychologically.
This experiment appears to test the ability and effectiveness of holding a pen between someone's teeth to perform several different activities.
To find new ways to help people w/disabilities or physical diformities in everyday life ex. People that lost hands/arms etc.
To test the quality of life of persons unable to perform tasks normally relative to the average person.

In the instructions, the purpose was stated to be a study of how well a task could be performed if I had a physical impariment.  I believe the purpose is to assess how people feel, both physically and emotionally, about performing simple tasks in an unusual way.
The purpose of this experiment was to see how my performance doing something new and unusual improved w/practice.
Either truly to see how well someone can use the pen in their mouth or how willing someone is to follow difficult instructions when they think they are helping others.
Something to do with facial expression but honestly I dunno
Social awareness in the development of new technology for special needs members of society

[NOTE: TECHNICAL PROBLEMS MEANT WE HAD NO VIDEO TO VERIFY TASK PERFORMANCE FOR THIS SUBJECT.] This experiment seems to be curious about whether people can complete these tasks using their mouth & whether they get frustrated by their ability/inability to perform the tasks satisfactorily.
to see if different parts of the body can be used in novel ways to preform everyday tasks (especially pertaining to people who may be unable to preform the tasks normally)
To study how someone who is not handicapped and is not actually limited ot this form of writing is able to do it and how they feel about it
For people who are unable to use their hands for writing activities
To see how difficult it is to do normal tasks with unusual parts of the body
To see how we perceive faces that we don't usually make and how others may impact our own self-awareness.
TO see if people think seeing someone writing with a pen in their mouth is weird.
Honestly I'm not entirely sure. At first I thought it would be a basic motor functions test, but the cartoons threw me for a loop. Possibly a test of self-image?
To evaluate the way in which strange/unexpected ways of doing things affects performance. How being self-conscious may affect performance on tasks.
Either: 1) to test the motor skills of the mouth or: 2) to see what effect not being able to completely smile and laugh had on how funny jokes/cartoons are perceived as.
To test a less common way of holding pens for those who do not have the use of their hands. Presumably a more common way involves the use of the lips.
The emotional psychology of how people with disabilities may feel when doing tasks similar to this because it may be their way of living.
To understand how people deal differently with unfamiliar tasks like this
This experiment was about multitasking. It was difficult to think about the task and doing it correctly while also concentrating on holding the pen the correct way at the same time.
To see how well people can use other parts of their bodies to complete tasks. It can probably help people design helpful devices more efficiently for those people who do have disabilities.
To learn about how ppl physically as well as emotionally/mentally may react and cope w/doing tasks w/ a diff part of the body that ppl normally use to do those tasks.

To see how difficult it is to perform tasks with body parts you don't normally use for those tasks. More importantly though, how using those unconventional body parts affects the person (performance, confidence, people's impression of them..etc)
To study how a person reacts to an adverse condition
The purpose of this experiment is to see if inexpensive solutions to physical impairments are viable (compare to expensive solutions).
To understand the difficulties for a person who always has to write like this, but also to gauge how quickly a person can learn to do it.
Maybe something to do with connections between confidence and a person's self-awareness?
To assess how well a person used to writing with implements held in their hands can adjust to writing with an implement in their mouth.

Being able to perform everyday tasks without the usual body part associated with that specific task and maybe how one thinks they would be perceived by others when using that atypical body part to perform a task and how this affects their overall performance.
To test the possibilites of using your mouth as an alternative to hands and how successful/hard it is.
To test out a method of writing/communicating that could be used by people without the use of their hands.
It seems like the purpose is to test coordination. It seems like there could also be a componet about comfort and response to humor.

The specific purpose of this experiment is to see how comfortable people are writing w/ a pen in their mouths and seeing how it affects one's mood. The overall purpose is to see people's ability to perform various tasks w/different parts of their body in order to assist people w/impairments.
To see how well we use different parts of our body for various tasks.
Perhaps to evaluate how people can write with a pen in their teeth. And eval. This position.

Test peoples abilities to hold a pen in their mouth, with the purpose of seeing is a similarily operated device may be helpful to those who cannot hold a pen a normal way, without impeading other everyday tasks that require concentration, and without causing too much stress or pain to the user so that such operation on a daily basis is feasible.
To understand the psychological impacts of having an impairment and how that impairment affects one's ability to do everyday tasks.

The purpose of the experiment is to determine how quickly one can adapt to using the mouth for tasks one does not normally use the mouth for, and to determine if emotion affects the success. The purpose may also be to determine how people cope with new challenges i.e. smiling at cartoon while trying to write with the mouth.

To evaluate how we use non-traditional or assumed parts of the body for actions - as in, one rarely thinks to use the teeth in order to stabilize/use a pen. Question/address self consciousness and effectiveness around non-traditional use after the completion of tasks.
column22: Independently designed major in the EV realm - Philosophy minor

column18: How well our body which we don't normally use function. Different people's ability to perform various tasks.
Evaluating performance of impaired abilities in writing/drawing. I also think there is a strong emphasis on gauging how proper form of technique limits performance.
See how perform tasks with mouth since there are people that must operate in this way
This experiment might evaluate how does the teeth tecnique interfere in the writing itself, saliva and confort
To help create technologies for people with disabilities, to find functional alternate (using alternate body parts) ways of completing tasks.
To test the ease with which people can preform simple and day-to-day tasks using different parts of the body.

I think the purpose of the experiment was two fold. One to show how difficult it is to carry out simple tasks while holding a pen in your mouth, instead of using your hnads. Two, to show that general amusement or our ability to find something funny is higher while holding a pen in this way. Possibly a correlation with mouth shape?
To see how people use their body parts to do things that they would not normally do with those body parts
To see how easily people can use tools in a way that is strange to them but not necessarily for others

I think the purpose of this experiment is to have people practice a method of writing that could be used for physically handicapped people (missing arms, fingers, or otherwise unable to write as most able people do). By having many people test this method, the experimenters can better assess the efficiency of implementing widespread use of this writing technique.
To determine feasibility of writing with the mouth as opposed to speech recognition software? To gauge peoples' discomfort with using unusual body parts for tasks.

I think the purpose of the experiment was to see how well simple tasks could be performed using one's mouth to control a pen, with the idea being that if someone could perform the tasks decently then expensive technologies would be proved unnecessary or at least not as vital as some believe they are. I think the study was also trying to research how one's level of embarassment/self-consciousness, due to writing with their mouth, would affect their performance.
To equate self-consciousness with performance on the tasks.
To see if it's feasible for people w/disabilities to function in this position and/or perform tasks.
"In this study we evaluate a simple & cheap alternative" -information brochure
To test people's abilities to perform motor skills in a less common/different way. To research how people's approaches to each task might have different results.
look at different peoples abilities, discomfort, and social discomfort when writing with a pen in their mouth

I think the purpose of this experiment is to use body parts that you don't normally use for everyday tasks (like writing). Ths can also represent how it feels if you are physically impaired (can't use your hands to write)
To see if holding a pen with your mouth and writing could be an effective way to write for people with disabilities, etc. An alternative to writing with your hands.

I think the purpose of this experiment is to test the best way to create a technology for people to be able to write with their mouths. I think it is specifically targeting people with physical disabilities who cannot write normally.

See how reasonable it is for people without typical hand/gripping capabilities to use their mouths to perform tasks done by normal people. Also, perhaps how well people can/will maintain correct/difficult positions
To test how behaviors and preformance would change when a person is forced to do simple tasks in an uncomfortable way.

I think the purpose of the experiment is to evaluate alternate ways in which to perform daily tasks so as to come up with different ways to think about how we complete tasks as well as to perhaps find solutions to helping people with disabilities find ways to complete tasks different ways. Perhaps the experiment was also meant to show how difficult it is to learn different methods of performing tasks we do every day with ease.
To test how people learn to do different tasks than they normally would with certain body parts…to help with research for creating tools to help disabled people
To test a grip, especially on things as simple/everyday as underlining/circling, for comfort + impact on legibility. Further to see instinctive ways to "master" the given technique.
I think the purpose of the experiment is to see whether people obey the given instruction or not when the instruction is not comfortable for them. (without people monitored)
I think the purpose of this experiment is to test how difficult it is to do something in a way that I wouldn't normally perform the task.
To study the ability of people to use fine motor skills around his/her mouth as a controller for specialized tools

I think the purpose is to find ways to examine how well we function doing everyday tasks with a different manner. I also believe that by choosing the method of how you hold the pen in your mouth is a way to challenge your brain.
To see how we can use parts of our bodies to complete tasks that do not usually require the use of that part of the body

My understanding was that the experiment was studying the effectiveness of using parts of one's body in place of another (mouth instead of hands) in order to ascertain what could be used as a low cost substitute for things/devices that would serve the same tasks for individuals with disabilities of a nature that made this technology a necessity.

I think the purpose is too see if individuals have difficulty utilizing an item in a way they have never used it before (i.e. pen in mouth, not in hand.) This shows the difficulty individuals have when they don't normally use an item (& muscles they don't use) in comparison to how they normally do use it.
The purpose of the experiment seemed to be to study the extent to which people could adapt their behavior & motor coordination to complete everyday tasks in an unusual manner.

1) Determine plausibility of mouth-held writing instruments for the disabled. 2) Gauge the effect of self-consciousness on one's ability to focus/perform 3) Mouth resembles a smile - does holding a smile have an affect on how humorous or enjoyable people find cartoons/media/life?
To evaluate ways in which technology can be used to help those with disabilities. Also to see the realistic effects on how it would impact the individual, socially

To measure people's ability to adapt to using a tool in an unfamiliar way. (Note tongue placement and teeth alignment affected by ability to perform tasks. Tongue placement was not specified in the instructions and could be used for leverage against the pen.)

To examine the effectiveness of simple solutions (i.e. holding pen in mouth) to disabilities which prevent one from using hands to hold pen. Also to gauge participants reaction, discomfort, etc. to using a pen in this way. …Or maybe it is all a coverup for some psychological experiment involving making people do bizarre tasks and gauging how they react, etc. I don't know!
To examine the drawbacks of holding a pen in this way
The purpose of this experiment was to see my ability to hold the pen in my mouth without using my teeth while writing/drawing.

I think that the purpose of this experiment was to study motor skills of the mouth (specifically not handeye). I also could be able the memory of muscles and how, since mouth is typically not holding/using a pen, I don't have the muscle memory to perform the tasks efficiently nor well.
To figure out what the assimilation of this kind of utilization of the mouth would look like and how practical it would be in a work/classroom setting.
To study how psychomotoric can effect the self conscious?
To look for alternative and less expensive ways to ease or facilitate writing or performing other daily tasks for people who are physically impaired.
To test people's coordination using their mouth for situation its usually not sued for. I don't really get the purpose of the cartoons

To get a better understanding of ways in which certain body parts may take on the role of other body parts in complex everyday tasks. This experiment could help in finding the most efficient ways to help those with disabilities.

To understand the social impacts that may go along with being able to execute a task using a body part you wouldn't normally use. Also to understand if using the mouth as a way to write is painful or not.
To test a new technology to aid people to write with an instrument held in their mouth.
Possibly link how people's physical disadvantages affect their sense of humor
To analyze how people interact with the camera and analyze if they look uncomfortable etc. Also, maybe to see if the mouth position changes w/laughter. Not sure.

The forms said this experiment was designed to see how people preform tasks with body parts not normally associated with those tasks. But usually these (psych experiments I've taken) have a hidden motive. You probably have one too, you sneaky researchers.

To find trends in how people perceive others holding pens/objects in weird/abnormal ways, such as when a person is disabled, or to see how naturally people can pick up/learn to hold in object in their mouth the correct way
To compare the awareness of one's own appearance to the success in completing simple tasks
To see how a person's ability to complete a task is affcted by a) social concerns and b) physical disabilities
To see how much it will affect on the quality of doing tasks using somewhere that is not normally use. Also how it will effect people's thinking process (like not understanding the cartoons)
To research ways of writing (or generally, communicating?) with parts of your body other than hands (e.g. for disabled individuals who can't use their hands to write)
